content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a risk-taker and someone who is always ready for a challenge, I would approach this game with a strategy that maximizes my potential earnings while considering the probability of the opponent's actions.

In this game, there are two possible outcomes when I pick R: either my opponent also picks R (earning 45$), or they pick B (earning 0$). If I pick B, I can earn up to 42$ when my opponent picks R and 12$ if they also pick B.

To maximize my earnings, I should focus on the scenarios where I earn the most money. In this case, that's when my opponent picks a different choice than me. Since earning 45$ when they pick R and 42$ when they pick B are higher than the possible earnings of 12$ when they also pick B, I would choose to pick R more often.

However, considering that this is a game with an anonymous player, it's difficult to know their strategy. If I assume that they are rational players like me, there might be a tendency for both players to pick the same choice over time due to the higher potential reward when we choose the same option (45$ each).

To avoid this, a strategy would be to alternate my choices in an attempt to maximize earnings. This way, I earn 42$ every time they pick R while I pick B and vice versa, as well as 12$ every time we both pick B. With 75 rounds, alternating between R and B results in 37 instances of earning 42$, 8 instances of earning 0$, 26 instances of earning 12$, and 4 instances where my opponent chooses the same as I do and we both earn 45$. This strategy yields a total payoff of approximately 1,514$ (37*42 + 26*12 + 8*0 + 4*45).

In conclusion, I would choose to alternate between R and B as my strategy in this game. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, since my opponent picked B and I picked R, I will earn nothing (0$). However, I still believe in alternating my choices to increase my overall earnings over the long run. Therefore, in the next round, I would choose B as a rational risk-taker seeking to maximize my potential payoff. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I picked B and my opponent also picked B, so we both earn 12$ each. While it's a lower payout compared to earning 45$, it still counts towards my overall earnings, especially when considering that I'm playing a long game of 75 rounds.

For the next round, since I previously chose R and my opponent picked B, they might consider switching their strategy and choosing R this time. To minimize their potential earnings and maximize mine, I will stick to my alternating strategy by picking R in the next round. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both my opponent and I picked R in the previous round, so we each earn 45$ as our payoff for that round. This is the maximum possible payout for a single round in this game.

For the next round, since my opponent also chose R last time, they might consider switching their strategy to B. To maximize my potential earnings, I will stick to my alternating strategy by picking B in the next round. {B}
